llm.feedback: Your draft is a solid first pass but still falls short of world‑class rigor. Add a concise scenario‑catalyst map (e.g., table with “Base”, “Bull”, “Bear” rows, triggers such as “Fed cuts 50‑100 bp”, “IPO volume > 90”, “China export‑control easing”, and invalidations like “Fed stalls”, “US‑China tensions spike”, “chip demand weakens”) and give each trigger a clear 3‑6 month window. Insert source IDs after every quantitative claim (e.g., revenue $215 m (SK994CBWR), guidance $850‑$950 m (SK994CBWR), 95 IPOs in 2025 vs 73 in 2024 (Q7VVGNSQE), 50‑bp cut in September (C22MKA9VY)). Explicitly note the 36 % price surge as a potential over‑valuation risk (SK994CBWR). Quantify upside more precisely: target $35.00 (≈12 % above $30.53) and alternative $38.00 if IPOs accelerate, $28.00 if Fed stalls. Add macro data (inflation 3.5 %, GDP growth 2.5 % 2025) and policy context (Fed’s 4.25‑4.5 % range, Treasury Secretary’s 150 bp call (C22MKA9VY)). Include a watch‑list with dates: Fed policy meeting (Sept 2025), IPO calendar, semiconductor order book releases. Finally, give a confidence rating (e.g., “moderate‑high”) and justify it with the firm’s high gross margin (49 % (SK994CBWR)), low debt (23 % (SK994CBWR)), and strong earnings growth (37 % (SK994CBWR)). These edits will tighten the causal chain, improve citation density, and align the analysis with the 3‑6 month horizon and scenario‑based structure required.
